Award.AwardTitle: Discontinuous Galerkin Schemes for Fluid, Kinetic, and Multiscale Fluid/Kinetic Models in Plasma Physics Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plasma physics is the study of the dynamics of ionized gases. Because plasma, often referred to as the fourth state of matter, is the most abundant form of ordinary matter in the universe, there exist many important application problems for which an understanding would be advantageous. The motivating application for this research is high-energy particle acceleration using laser-plasma interactions. The production of high-energy particle beams is important in the process of creating synchrotron radiation, which is used for small scale imaging in many application areas including materials science, biology, and medicine. Laser-plasma acceleration is a mechanism for generating high-energy electrons by hitting a plasma with a specifically-tuned ultra-short laser beam. This approach provides the possibility to create high-energy particles with a device much smaller than standard particle accelerators. The big challenge with this approach is to be able to generate a relativistic electron beam with a small energy spread. The objective of this research is to develop highly accurate and efficient computational methods for simulating the acceleration of high-energy electrons. This research aims to develop novel computational techniques for so-called 'kinetic models' of plasma that achieve accuracy and robustness by exactly conserving certain important properties (e.g., mass and energy conservation and positivity of the solution). These methods will be implemented in computer code that will take advantage of modern computer architectures. The resulting methods will be used to simulate various scenarios of laser-plasma interactions with the aim to elucidate the mechanisms of electron acceleration and the features of the produced electron bream.

The primary objective of this research is to develop accurate and efficient computational methods for solving nonlinear partial differential equations used to model plasma dynamics. The mathematical models considered in this work arise from an important application problem: laser plasma accelerators, which provide a promising mechanism for generating high-energy electrons by hitting a plasma with a specifically-tuned ultra-short laser beam. The research will focus on developing efficient high-order discontinuous Galerkin schemes for kinetic Vlasov systems. The two main challenges that will be addressed are the development of (1) efficient time-stepping procedures that allow for time-steps that are dictated by physically important time scales and (2) high-order discretizations that numerically conserve important physical properties such as mass, momentum, and energy, as well as properties such as the positivity of the solution. One approach that will be explored in this research in order to improve the efficiency of the kinetic Vlasov numerical methods is the coupling of kinetic Vlasov solvers to fluid solvers to obtain a multiscale fluid/kinetic method. Part of the work will be done in collaboration with an experimental physicists, Prof. Dr. Malte Kaluza (Jena), who will help guide the mathematical modeling in order to keep the models relevant to the important physics of laser-plasma accelerators. Correspondingly, the resulting computational results will be used to influence laser-plasma experiments. The software that will result from this research project, along with proper
documentation, will be made freely available on the web as part of the open-source package DoGPack.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computational science is a multidisciplinary field that encompasses design of algorithms, design of computer software, design of computer hardware, and the interaction of these issues with science application-specific problems. The methods that were developed as part of this funded research project fall into the design of algorithms part of computational science. The main challenge in the design of algorithms is to simultaneously optimize both the (1) accuracy and (2) efficiency of the algorithm. It is often the case that the goals of accuracy and efficiency are intertwined in complex ways.

One key aspect of the accuracy and efficiency assessment of a numerical algorithm is the question of the smoothness properties of the solution. If the solution is sufficiently smooth, so-called "high-order" methods (aka, spectral or spectral element methods) are often the most accurate and efficient choices. If the solution has very little smoothness (or even discontinuities), "low-order" methods tend to be much more efficient and are imbued with the ability to easily preserve important properties of the solution, thus also making them more accurate. The difficulty is that for many realistic applications the solution is sufficiently smooth in some regions of the problem and not very smooth in others. The key in such situations is to dynamically switch between "low-order" and "high-order" methods.

The funded work addresses the problem of dynamic switching between high and low order methods in the context of simulating fluid dynamics in complex geometries. To this end the research team developed new strategies that allows existing high-order methods to reduce to low-order methods whenever a newly designed indicator function flags a particular region in the computational domain. Furthermore, the research team developed strategies that allow these adaptive approaches to also maintain important physical properties such as the positivity of certain physical quantities (e.g., mass density and thermal pressure). Application problems from compressible gas dynamics where solved using these newly developed algorithms.

Another aspect of efficiency for time-dependent problems is the size of the time-step that the underlying algorithm allows relative to some time-scale that is important to the specific application. If a method is to be efficient, each time-step should be as computationally inexpensive as possible and the number of times should be minimized. These two requirements are often at odds with each other.

The funded work addresses this issue for an important class of partial differential equations known as “hyperbolic partial differential equations”; such equations arise in many application areas with wave-like phenomena (e.g., acoustics, elasticity, water wave dynamics, gas dynamics, and plasma physics). A new time-stepping method was developed that overcame a previously known time-step restriction by using a novel solution reconstruction approach. The idea is to first write solution update into two parts: (1) a predictor and (2) a corrector. The key improvement was to modify the predictor so that it used more information about the solution than previously developed methods. A rigorous analysis was carried out to prove that the newly developed methods do indeed allow for larger time-steps. The increased stability allowed by this new approach is especially beneficial for problems in multiple space dimensions.

The improved algorithms developed in this work will be used by the PI and his research team in future work to tackle a variety of application problems. Current efforts are underway to apply the results of the funded research to study several important problems in plasma physics, including (1) fast magnetic reconnection and (2) laser-plasma accelerators. Fast magnetic reconnection is an instability that can develop in highly conducting plasma. The instability occurs when oppositely directed magnetic fields first merge and then re-emerge in a different topological configuration. Laser-plasma acceleration is a mechanism for generating high-energy electrons by hitting a plasma with a specifically-tuned ultra-short laser beam. This approach provides the possibility to create high-energy particles with a device much smaller than standard particle accelerators. Accurate and efficient numerical methods are required to simulate these phenomena; the research developed in this funded grant is an important step in achieving such methods.
